section5List.hed: The Simplest, Fastest, 2-Ingredient Dessert of Summer
section5List.dek: The perfect summer dessert requires just two things: fresh fruit and strong booze.
section5List.promoHed: The Simplest, Fastest, 2-Ingredient Dessert of Summer
section5List.body:
Sometimes I find that at the end of dinnerespecially long dinners on hot summer nightsthe thought of digging into a big, baked dessert, [even a blueberry crisp](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes-menus/how-to-make-fruit-crisps-without-a-recipe-article), can feel like too much. On those sticky, heavy nights, I drink my dessert instead.

[#article: /articles/5578a69974cbe9ed7c20a074]||||||

But I do it with fruit. Because no matter how much I've eaten, I can always eat fresh fruit. Especially summer's ripest peaches, berries, melons, and cherries. 

Some of you may be rolling your eyes. Trust me, when I suggest we "just eat fruit" for dessert, I hear grumbles from certain dessert lovers in my life, too. But that's the point of pairing fruit and booze. When you slice fruit, put it in a fancy bowl, and pour a bit of booze over it (and maybe a splash of heavy cream) (or ice cream!), "just fruit" turns into something much more. 

The pairings you put together will be dependent on what ripe fruitand what open bottlesyou have on hand. But I have a few favorites that I like to keep supplies for on hand.

Melon and port is a classic pairing. When cantaloupes are at their sweetest, heaviest, and ripest, I slice them in half, scoop out the seeds and pour port into the cavity. Then all you need is a spoon (or two, if you're sharing) to scoop out juicy spoonfuls of port-stained melonan activity that feels simultaneously decadent, old-fashioned, and viscerally poetic.

Fresh cherries and vanilla cream (be it [whipped](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/vanilla-whipped-cream-5625) or ice cream) is simpler and lighter than an all-out sundae. And when you add a splash of amaro (lean towards a sweeter option in this case, rather than a bitter one), it turns downright seductive. (Amaretto is also nice here.) 

And when there are still bottles of wine open on that table? That's when I fill everybody's glass with bubbles or riesling and slip in sweet slices of peach. Strawberries and raspberries are natural fits too, alone or along with those peaches. When you reach the bottom of the glass, don't be shy about fishing out the wine-soaked fruit and popping it into your mouth. Otherwise you're just drinking. And this isn't just a drinkthis is dessert.

section5List.hed: How to Make Your Own Chocolate Shell with Just Two Ingredients
section5List.dek: This crunchy, cocoa-flavored ice-cream topping might not technically be magical, but it is amazingly easy.
section5List.promoHed: How to Make Your Own Chocolate Shell with Just Two Ingredients
section5List.seoTitle: How to Make Your Own Chocolate Shell with Just Two Ingredients
section5List.socialTitle: How to Make Your Own Chocolate Shell with Just Two Ingredients
section5List.body:
Growing up, few things were greater than seeing a bottle of Magic Shell at a birthday party next to the cake and ice cream.

For the unfamiliar, this syrupy concoction that hardens into a shell was a staple at every gathering that involved a DIY ice cream bar. It comes in various flavors (like caramel and even root beer) but I think we can all agree that chocolate fudge was the real deal.

I personally liked to use a 2:1 ratio of shell to ice cream when I was a kid. Sometimes I would just freeze a plate, pour Magic Shell all over it, and scrape away with a fork. My chocoholic tendencies continued well into adulthood, which is why I was delighted to discover that this addictive coating, believe it or not, is hardly "magic." You can even make it yourself with just two ingredients, and it's still every bit as great when you're older. Besides adding it to sundaes, you can also make your own chocolate covered ice cream bars or dip fruits in it. Here how it's done:

__For 1 cup of chocolate shell, you'll need:__

2 cups good quality chocolate, finely chopped

1/4 cup refined coconut oil

__Directions:__

1. Add the chocolate to a microwave-safe bowl or container along with the coconut oil.

2. Microwave, in 30 second intervals, until completely melted.

3. Pour it over ice cream and watch the magic happen (allow 30 seconds before you try to crack it. You will know it's ready when the shell turns from glossy to matte). Note: If the chocolate shell re-hardens as you use it, you can just microwave it again (briefly) until liquidy.

__Here are some things we want to smother or dip in homemade chocolate shell:__

[#recipe: /recipes/54a421586529d92b2c008855]|||
Peanut Butter Ice Cream with a Hard Chocolate Shell

Who says ice cream floats are just for kids? Here, the bitter aperitif Aperol spikes the sweet and juicy berries.
While the recipe calls for making your own meringue cookies, we won't tell anyone if you make it easier on yourself and use store-bought ones.
Think zucchini bread can't be dessert? It absolutely can be when it's sprinkled with sugar and grilled until caramelized.
Because if you don't have blueberry juice running down your wrists while watching fireworks, you're not doing it right.

section5List.dek: It's time to move beyond chocolate and vanilla.
section5List.promoDek: It's time to move beyond chocolate and vanilla.
section5List.promoHed: 6 Cookies. 6 Ice Creams. Endless Ice Cream Sandwich Possibilities.

items.caption: These decadent double chocolate cookies mimic the soft chocolate shortbread you find in traditional store-bought ice cream sandwiches (only much better, natch). We particularly like using these, and other chewy texture cookies, for ice cream sandwiches, because they're super easy to bite through.

items.title: Cherry-Packed Bourbon Ice Cream
items.caption: [Chocolate](https://epicurious.conde.io/recipes/food/views/51210520) goes with just about every ice cream flavor: [caramel](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/burnt-caramel-ice-cream-237026), [coffee](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/coffee-cardamom-ice-cream-with-figs-51183690), [mint](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/isaac-mizrahis-mint-chocolate-chip-ice-cream-240235), [raspberry](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/raspberry-cassis-ice-cream-235175), more [chocolate](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/chocolate-ice-cream-365792). But it might go best with cherries.

For a simple and classic ice cream sandwich, try this variation on the [sugar cookie](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/sugar-cookies-51113460). Brown sugar adds a slightly deeper and richer flavor; if you want even more, try folding citrus zest or chopped candied ginger into the dough.

items.title: Chocolate-Malt Ice Cream
items.caption: Stick with the simple beat and pair that [sugar cookie](https://epicurious.conde.io/recipes/food/views/brown-sugar-cookies-367569) with good old fashioned chocolate ice cream. Adding chopped malted milk balls in this recipe adds pops of texture in every bite, a nice surprise hidden into a cookie sandwich.
These oat-packed cookies also happen to be gluten-free, perfect for ice cream sandwiches that everybody can eat (except, um, vegans). For more crunch, add toasted walnuts into the dough.

Combining [oatmeal](https://epicurious.conde.io/recipes/food/views/51210520) with banana is a bit like giving your morning cereal bowl the dessert treatment. This ice cream combines *cajeta*, a Mexican goat's milk caramel, with banana, for something similar to *dulce de leche*. We'd also happily pair oatmeal cookies with [cinnamon ice cream](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/cinnamon-ice-cream-107333) or [salted caramel](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/salted-caramel-ice-cream-354517).
For a slightly savory ice cream sandwich, turn to this buttery shortbread. Although triangles are pretty for tea party platters, we'd cut them into rectangles for ice cream sandwiches.

Pair that [rich buttery shortbread](https://epicurious.conde.io/recipes/food/views/black-sesame-brown-sugar-shortbread-51256860) with this tangy sorbet for a dessert that's both decadent and refreshing.

These cookies add a couple interesting elements to ice cream sandwiches: The rye flour adds nuttiness, and rolling the cookie dough in [sanding sugar](https://www.cakes.com/products/sanding-sugar-white-4-oz-6235) adds sparkle.

Pair the nuttiness of that [rye flavor](https://epicurious.conde.io/recipes/food/views/salted-rye-cookies-51123200) with peanuts for double the richness. [Caramel](https://epicurious.conde.io/recipes/food/views/chestnut-caramel-ice-cream-231323) or [chocolate ice cream](https://epicurious.conde.io/recipes/food/views/chocolate-ice-cream-231817) would also be delicious with those cookies.
Ice cream sandwiches don't have to be made with cookies. Try out these easy brownies for a version that is sure to please. (Pro tip: Make them a little thinner for manageable sandwiches.)

There's no doubt that [brownies](https://epicurious.conde.io/recipes/food/views/51134540) and cheesecake are a winning combination. And sure, you can serve the brownies al a mode, but isn't it so much fun to make them into a sandwich?

items.title: Bonus Tip: Dip 'Em!
items.caption: Go a step further with your ice cream sandwich creations by coating one end in melted chocolate, then dipping them in a variety of toppings, such as sprinkles, chopped nuts, or crushed candy.

section5List.hed: How to Keep Ice Cream Fresh Longer
section5List.promoHed: The Best Way to Keep Ice Cream Fresh
section5List.body:
Youve picked up the finest pint at the store. [Maybe you've even made your own ice cream](https://epicurious.conde.io/recipes/food/views/true-vanilla-ice-cream-51179020). Youve sampled a little (or maybe a lot) before shutting it into the freezer. But when ice cream craving strikes again, what will you find in the container? 

[#article: /articles/54ad516819925f464b3b4b26]||||||

Winter, in the form of freezer burn, has arrived. It's shattered what was once delightful about ice cream. Chocolate ice. Glaciers of vanilla. Blizzards of butter pecan. We feel your pain.

Short of eating the entire carton in one sitting, here's how to preserve your favorite ice cream.

##Freezer Burn: Ice Cream's Worst Nightmare##

Why does freezer burn happen? When food is exposed to air in a freezer (like in a non-airtight container), [the cold temperature reacts with the oxygen](http://www.fsis.usda.gov/wps/portal/fsis/topics/food-safety-education/get-answers/food-safety-fact-sheets/safe-food-handling/freezing-and-food-safety/CT_Index), which dehydrates the food at the surface. 

We checked in with Cary Frye, of [the International Dairy Foods Association](http://www.idfa.org/), who specializes in ice cream (um, dream job?). She broke things down for us. "If ice cream is left out and refrozen, you're going to get larger crystals, which are going to feel coarse, icy, and even colder on your tongue," Frye says, "The second quality defect with ice cream is the evaporation of water at ice cream's surface level, and that forms additional ice crystals that you can see."

When ice cream is commercially frozen, a manufacturer's goal is to freeze the ice cream with small and uniform ice crystals. As ice cream thaws and refreezes, these ice crystals can get bigger and less uniformthat's the patches of ice you see in some spots. While freezer burn won't hurt, it certainly isnt fun to eat, as anyone who tries to burnt ice cream will try to tell you while chomping on ice particles.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4265c19925f464b37b8e1]||||||

##Don't Let Freezer Burn Happen to Good Ice Cream##

To keep your ice cream burn-free, you want to minimize oxygen exposure. How? We didn't want to split hairs too much, but it's Frye's job to split hairs and recommend the best ways to keep ice cream. The former food technologist and current ice cream expert gave us her own hacks for protecting ice cream.

Frye places a piece of plastic wrap directly on top of the ice cream before replacing the lid. By minimizing permeable surfaces, you're making less places for the ice cream to be exposed to air. This won't make your ice cream invincible, but it's enough to keep it fresh for a little bit longer.

Ice cream placement within the freezer also can make or break ice cream. The freezer, much like an oven, has a temperature control, but some spots are warmer than others. Keeping the temperature stable prevents fluctuations in the ice cream that build larger lumps of ice. Though pint containers fit almost too perfectly, don't keep ice creams in the door. The door experiences the most temperature fluctuation from opening and closing. Our favorite place to store? Deep in the back, where there's less exposure to the outside air.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4234e6529d92b2c0099bf]||||||

section3List.hed: The Blueprint for Our Not-So-Secret Burger Sauce
section3List.dek: A closely-guarded sauce recipe is the hallmark of any classic burger. We made our own, but aren't being so hush-hush about it.
section3List.promoHed: The Blueprint for Our Not-So-Secret Burger Sauce
section3List.seoTitle: How to Make Your Own Hamburger Secret Sauce at Home
section3List.seoDescription: A closely-guarded sauce recipe is the hallmark of any classic burger. We made our own, but aren't being so secretive about it.
section3List.socialTitle: How to Make Your Own Hamburger Secret Sauce at Home
section3List.socialDescription: A closely-guarded sauce recipe is the hallmark of any classic burger. We made our own, but aren't being so secretive about it.
section3List.body:
My childhood consisted of more fast-food hamburgers than my mother would probably care to admit. Don't get me wrongshe had dinner on the table at least five nights a week and we ate as a family. But, whether it was after school with friends or on one of those days when, for whatever reason, dinner at home wasn't an option, a trip to the drive-through meant a burger in my hands. Squishy seeded buns, plastic-perfect looking tomatoes, and cooked-through patties are great and all, but I spent time being enamored with one drive-through hamburger constantthe mythical secret sauce. 

[#article: /articles/54b80f32ac90eb2c34cfcd6e]||||||

Because, of course I was. Mayo laced with secrets is a kid's dream condiment. Fast forward a couple of decades later and not much has changed. Recently, I [went behind-the-scenes at Shake Shack](www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-make-shake-shack-burger-at-home-epicurious-secrets-article) to learn the burger-flipping ropes, and my biggest object of fascination was the chain's "Shack Sauce." How good can Shack Sauce really be? As Shake Shack Culinary Director Mark Rosati put it to me: "The idea behind the sauce is adding that flavor and lubrication that takes things from amazing to overdrive." 

The other thing Rosati told me is that there's so much going on in their sauce that people "can't really recreate it" at home. So, naturally, I headed back to the Epicurious Test Kitchen to try. Somewhere between attempt #127 and #324, food editor Rhoda Boone and I got pretty close. Then we kept tinkering, and tinkering. Soon, we had a secret sauce that was all our own. 

Or, rather, a [Not-So-Secret Sauce](epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/Epicurious-Not-So-Secret-Sauce-51261820). We'll tell you upfront that our sauce has a base layer of mayo, ketchup, and yellow ballpark mustard, and a slew of flavor-boosting ingredients that yield the same unctuous fattiness of the all-time great secret saucesbut with a bit more spice. Vinegar is a great way to balance out the fat of mayonnaise with acid, so we used the juice from spicy pickles combined with three key spices: smoked paprika, garlic powder, and onion powder. The result is a complex flavor bomb that gives our [Classic Smashed Cheeseburger](http://presentation.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/Classic-Smashed-Cheeseburger-51261810) it's over-the-top flavor advantage. 

The list of ingredients that could find their way into your secret sauce are endless. Want to make a condiment that's on the sweeter side? Add more ketchup and toss some relish in there. Need more spice? Bust out the cayenne pepper. 

But we'd be honored if you tried our recipe, as is, at least once. Just don't blame us if you start putting it on everything you eat.

section3List.hed: Sandwiches from Sea to Shining Sea
section3List.seoDescription: Eat America between two slices of bread with these regional sandwiches.
section3List.socialDescription: Eat America between two slices of bread with these regional sandwiches.

items.caption: Whether it's mustard sauce in the South, vinegar in North Carolina, or white sauce in Alabama: it doesn't matter where you come from, we are all united in a serious obsession with barbecue. This vinegar-laced sandwich needs the chopped slaw for crunch.

The only thing that's missing here is the seaside view. A soft-shell lobster roll (dressed in either mayo or butter) is summer in sandwich form for New Englanders. For a herbal kick, mix chopped tarragon into your sandwich dressing.
The patty melt is a diner staple, best enjoyed as a break from a long trip through America's heartland.

Flecked with garlic and tomato sauce, the meatball hoagie is an Italian-American staple. We've made it a little healthier by subbing in turkey. If you're proud to be a super garlic head, lather the hoagie buns with a garlic butter.
The bread is essential to a New Orleansstyle French rolluse a crumby, unfussy French roll and lots of Crystal hot sauce.

Though you could say the Reuben sandwich came from a lightning strike of genius, it actually came from Omaha. This combo Reuben lays on the corned beef and pastrami with plenty of creamy Russian dressing. Serve with potato salad for a real all-American combo.

Wave your arm in Miami, and you'd practically hit six places to get a ham and pork Cubano. The big Cuban population in the city inspired this hearty sandwich, which usually pulls from a leftover pig roast.
The Southern-inspired sandwich is like a greatest hits: Fried chicken, buttery biscuits, and a hearty dousing of hot sauce. Breakfast or dinner? We can't pick.
What would a list of American sandwiches be without a burger? One that's missing everything. This smashed burger needs the special sauce.
From Hawaii to Maine, a fish sandwich is required eating for the warmer months. We tried a lot of twists before settling on this airy but crunchy winner.
Lox bagels are great for plenty of reasons: smoked salmon. And you don't need more reasons than that.
Like so many great American traditions, the grilled cheese gets even better with some unique flourishes; in this case, prosciutto and a jammy tomato spread.
How to make a Southern-fried BLT: top it with some fried green tomatoes, which are a little more acidic and bright than your standard supermarket variety.
The Philadelphia cheesesteak, in slider form. Same classic cheesesteak, in an easy-to-tackle size. If you're a purist, by all means use spray cheese instead of the recipe's provolone.

items.caption: These oysters get a double hit of smoke: one from the coals, another from a chipotle vinaigrette.
Grilled corn doesn't need much gussying upa simple herb butter is all you need.
The fresher the fish, the better the dish. This one is a showstopper that can either be sourced close to the shore or at your local fishmonger.
Because man can't live on seafood alone, we figured some vegetables might do you good. This cucumber salad is sturdy enough to make at home and pack for the beach.
This isn't your typical boring potato salad. These potatoes get kissed by the grill before they're tossed with chopped dill pickles.
Make a pitcher of sangria before you head to the beach for one less thing to worry about when you get there.
What could be better after a day of beachy fun than a slice of cool, refreshing key lime pie straight from the cooler?

Competition for the best burger in London has gone mad. Some burgers are gourmet and piled high with toppings, whereas others are thinner, simpler, wrapped in paper, steamy and sloppy. All I can say is my insanity burger is going to be right up therethe method is almost ritualistic in what it requires you to do to get close to burger perfection. I've also used the brilliant technique of brushing the burgers with mustard and a dash of Tabasco Chipotle sauce as they cook to build up an incredible gnarly layer of seasoning.

section2List.hed: The Margarita-Ros Cocktail Mashup Your Summer Needs
section2List.seoTitle: The Margarita-Ros Cocktail Mashup Your Summer Needs
section2List.seoDescription: The recipe for The Mos, a margarita made with ros wine.
section2List.socialTitle: The Margarita-Ros Cocktail Mashup Your Summer Needs
section2List.body:
As soon as June hits, my drinking regimen undergoes two seismic shifts.

[#article: /articles/54c14e0ee231becc7f3db37b]||||||

First, I start making pitchers of margaritas. Mine only have three ingredients: Tequila, lime juice, and agave syrup. They're boozy, punchy, and not too sweet. 

The second shift: I break out the dry ros. 

Which got me thinking: Why can't a cocktail combine all the best parts of a margaritabracing blanco tequila, loads of citrus, and a bit of sweet sugarwith the pure summery bliss of a glass of ros?

I'm here to tell you that it can. 

Meet [The Mos](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/the-mose-56389689)it's the margarita-ros mashup I've always wanted. 

I'm always looking to work seasonal produce into my house cocktailswhether it's [rhubarb](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes-menus/the-spring-house-cocktail-with-rhubarb-gin-and-ginger-article), [arugula](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes-menus/green-vesper-vegetable-cocktail-recipes-article), or [rosemary](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/rosemary-infused-spring-cocktail-article). It's summer and not using fresh-from-the-market strawberries whenever possible should considered a legal offense. So for my Mos, rather than use agave syrup like I would in a margarita, I simply top a couple of sliced strawberries with a bit of sugar and muddle until it's dissolved into a sweet, pulpy mess. 

Next comes high-quality blanco tequila. I'm a big fan of those made by [Casa Dragones](http://casa-dragones.1-877-spirits.com/blanco), [Astral](http://www.getwineonline.com/sku31865_ASTRAL-TEQUILA-BLANCO-750ML), and [Casa Noble](http://www.astorwines.com/SearchResultsSingle.aspx?search=21561). In the shaker it goes with some fresh lemon juice (lime clashed with the delicate sweetness of the strawberries by announcing itself too loudly) and a bit of ros. 

A note on the ros: You'll want to find a dry bottle from Provence, not something fruity and sweet. (Need more info? We've [got a guide for that](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/a-complete-guide-to-drinking-rose-wine-this-summer-article).)

Shake it all together with a large ice cube (we're talking [2 inches wide](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/guide-to-cocktail-ice-shapes-article) or larger here) and pour the whole thing without straining into a rocks glass. Why no straining? Because then you'd be wasting all those delicious chunks of strawberries. And that big ice cube's criticalit almost acts as an ingredient in and of itself, gradually diluting the tequila's boozy heat over the course of the first half of the drink. 

I'm not sure why it took so long for the margarita and ros to get together like this. I'm just glad it finally happened. 

[#recipe: /recipes/5570a6b181ac1e5023671d01]||||||

section2List.hed: The Best Cocktails for Serving a Crowd
section2List.dek: Making cocktails for a group can be a tall order, but only if you overcomplicate things. Do yourself a favor and skip the fancy, 10-ingredient cocktails. Instead, master a few punches and drinks that scale up to pitcher size easily.
section2List.promoDek: Making cocktails for a group can be a tall order, but only if you overcomplicate things. Do yourself a favor and skip the fancy, 10-ingredient cocktails. Instead, master a few punches and drinks that scale up to pitcher size easily.

section2List.socialTitle: The Best Cocktails for Serving a Crowd

items.title: Find Your Favorite Equal Parts Cocktail
items.caption: It doesn't get easier than making cocktails made with an equal parts ingredient list. The negroni is a classic: It's a potent, bitter combination of equal parts gin, Campari, and sweet vermouth. Having a crowd over? Dump a bottle of each into a pitcher and stir.

items.title: Go Big With a Homemade Shrub
items.caption: Creating a shruba vinegar-based syrupis a quick way to add sweetness and acid to any cocktail. The one used here uses tangy rhubarb and gets a slight kick from fresh ginger. Want a non-alcoholic version? Just skip the gin.

items.title: Make a Gin Punch
items.caption: It's as simple as thispunches were made for crowds. This one combines gin, the French liqueur crme de framboise, fresh fruit, and a sparkling wine topper.

items.title: Or Let Champagne Be the Star of the Show
items.caption: This punch prominently features the iconic French sparkling wineit calls for the whole bottle.

items.title: Infuse Your Own Booze
items.caption: The rosemary-infused vodka in this drink may sound fancy, but it couldn't be easier to make. Make a double batch (start the process a day before your party) and get your juicing arm ready for a whole lot of lemons and grapefruits.

items.title: Make Sangria
items.caption: Because who doesn't love wine mixed with fruit? Want to avoid making it taste like the syrupy, watered stuff you get in chain restaurants? Use fresh fruit that's in season and don't make this one too far in advance.

items.title: Upgrade the Margarita
items.caption: We all know that margaritas practically *belong* in a pitcher. Make this versionit swaps out sticky, sweet triple sec for pure, clean agave syrup.

items.title: Make a Spiced Simple Syrup
items.caption: A boozy whiskey cocktail that's equal parts mezcal smoke and festive sweetness, thanks to a warm, spice-infused maple syrup.

items.title: Make Next-Level Gin and Tonics
items.caption: It doesn't get much easier than G&Ts. All you need is club soda, gin, and a high-quality tonic syrup (we like the stuff the folks at [Jack Rudy Cocktail Co.](http://jackrudycocktailco.com/) make).

section2List.hed: 5 Add-Ins That Will Make Your Beer Better
section2List.dek: Add these to your mug for better drinking.
section2List.promoHed: How to Make Beer Even Better
section2List.body:
What's better than an ice cold beer on a sunny day? Think of these as beer pluscombos of your favorite brews and delicious add-ins that bring your beverage from plain Jane to cocktail town. Whether you are looking for a way to jazz up your six-pack or extend your beer's drinkability for an all day fest, these additions are sure to keep your stein delicious.

##Beer + Juice##
Just how do the beer-loving Germans get away with drinking all day? They turn to the Radler, AKA the Shandy, AKA a 50:50 mix of beer and juice that turns into a nice refreshing drink. The classic Radler is made with lemonade, but you can also take a page from Sunday brunch and mix in OJ for a fresh take on the Mimosa. 

+++landscape-justified


[#image: /photos/54ac3cfd19925f464b3a96db]||||||



+++

Light and fruity wheat beers work well here, but if you prefer heartier beers, a stout with orange juice is also pretty delicious. Try out other juices too, including blood orange, grapefruit, or even banana juice (which will up the banana notes in hefeweizens.)

##Beer + Soda##
This combo is like a Radler, but with even more bubbles. In Italy, you can find the Diesel drink, a combination of draft beer and cola, while in Cuba, it's popular to drink the Bul, a light beer with ginger ale. 

You can also use orange or lemon-lime soda, and even root beer. In fact, we'd add that last one to a creamy stout for an [over the top boozy float](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/stout-floats-238690).

##Beer + Hot Sauce##
Can't get enough heat? The original Mexican beer cocktail, [the Michelada](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/michelada-242665), combines a light, refreshing beer with the flavors of salsahot sauce, tomato juice, lime, and/or spices. Think of these as kind of like beer-y Bloody Marys.

##Beer + Booze##
Beer also plays well with cocktails. Light beers like pale ales, pilsners, and white beers work well in refreshing drinks, while stouts, porters, and brown ales can hold up to richer flavors. 

+++landscape-justified



[#image: /photos/54b40110d5e8c3e1070ad49e]||||||



+++

Pour in some beer in your next Whiskey Ginger, upgrade your [Aperol Spritz](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/aperol-mist-51238330) with some Belgian wheat beer, combine Champagne and stout for the classic Black Velvet, or add in some light beer to your next batch of [margaritas](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/beeritas-51144410).

##Beer + Beer##
The Snakebite, the Black and Tan, the Half and Halfno matter the name, these drinks are all varieties of beer-on-beer action. They work well when combining two very different styles: think dark lager plus pale ales, or stouts plus lambics. 

Raspberry lambic gives porter [a fruity twist](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/raspberry-snakebite-51240410), while a pilsner can help lighten up a hoppy double Indian pale ale. Plus you can layer the different colored beers to create a presentation that looks much harder to create than it is.

section2List.dek: Cocktail historian and pro Dave Wondrich filled our minds with cocktail knowledge on a recent Friday afternoon at the Epicurious offices. Our punch bowls will never be the same.
section2List.body:
Its woefully empty," says Wondrich, looking at his punch glass. "That simply wont do.

If you don't know Wondrich, he's the Drinks Correspondent for *Esquire* and one of the foremost voices on cocktail history and all things drink-making. And if you haven't pored over his foundational cocktail text [*Imbibe!*](http://www.amazon.com/Imbibe-Updated-Revised-Edition-Professor/dp/0399172610/ref=pd_sim_b_2?ie=UTF8&refRID=0SDHCFBKZECQAD9TENC4), there's no better time than nowan updated and revised version of the book was released last month. 

But, right now, Dave Wondrich is thirsty. And when the man has an empty punch glass, you fill it. 

He's come by the Epicurious offices to school us about the glory of America's first cocktail. After all, the man literally wrote the book on the subject with his 2010 book *[Punch: The Delights (and Dangers) of the Flowing Bowl](http://www.amazon.com/Punch-Delights-Dangers-Flowing-Bowl/dp/0399536167)*. 

The first revelatory piece of information I learn: The key to a great punch is a flavorful base, not necessarily the booze you use. Around this time of year, Wondrich loves to make fresh citrus the star of the show. "I brought the *oleo-saccharum*," exclaims Wondrich when he walks into the room. And, while it sounds like something out of a *Harry Potter* book, it's actually his secret sauce for the punch we're about to makea sealed mason jar filled with crystalized sugar and lemon peels. 

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/5548f653c4e7df4e33160b93]||||||

+++

"Over the course of a few hours in the sun, the sugar sucks up all of the moisture from the peels," explains Wondrich. That moisture is lemon oil, which he tells me is the best part of the lemon. "It's got great, well, lemon-y flavor and adds depth to the lemon juice I'm about to combine with it." We add water and lemon juice to the jar, shake the bejesus out of it, and*voil*!a base is born. 

The result is a sweet, tangy, supercharged version of the lemon flavor we all know. "It's like using two shades of color next to one another in a painting," muses Wondrich. "One supports the other and makes the whole better."

Of course, the type of rum used is also important when making rum punch. How strong do you want the rum to be? "You want real, old school Jamaican rum," explains Wondrich. "You can't use white rum. You want some real pirate juicesomething that, on it's own, is too funky to drink." He likes [Smith & Cross Jamaican Rum](http://www.astorwines.com/SearchResultsSingle.aspx?search=21937) because it's high proof, smoky, funky, and, at $29, doesn't break the bank.

To finish, Dave pulls out a small nutmeg grater and showers the bowl with the toasty aromatic. "You know, back in the 18th Century, gentlemen used to carry little, silver nutmeg graters in their pockets at all times so they could grate it over their punch." (In case you were wondering, those go for [thousands of dollars on eBay](http://www.ebay.com/itm/Sterling-Silver-Nutmeg-Shaped-Nutmeg-Grater-1870-H-T-/291437162977?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_3&hash=item43db0231e1)and even Dave doesnt have one.)

The process of making this punch is boneheadly simple. It's the kind of recipe you can't forget and can break out whenever a punch-crazed horde of guests heads your way. This recipe below makes enough for 24: 

*Place the __peels of 3-4 bright yellow lemons__ in a mason jar with __3/4 cup sugar__. Seal, shake, and let sit for at least 3-4 hours (and up to 8) in the sun. When you're ready to make the punch, open the jar and add __3/4 cups strained lemon juice__. Seal and shake until sugar has dissolved. Pour contents of jar into punch bowl, add one __750 ML bottle of rum__, __1 quart water__, and a lot of ice. Grate __nutmeg__ over top. Drink.* 

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/5548f640c4e7df4e33160ae1]||||||

+++

And those candied lemon peels from the *oleo-saccharum*? Don't toss themthey're the perfect garnish for your now-filled punch bowl. 

After Dave left us, I realized that we hadn't landed on a name for the punch he seemingly created out of thin air. So I emailed him, asking what we should call the thing. Dave responded immediately and proved nothing he says is pulled out of thin air: 

"That was the 'Sam Fraunces Punch,' in tribute to Samuel Fraunces, of Fraunces tavern, who appears to have been Jamaican and kept taverns all over lower Manhattan in the 18th Century. The punch is a straight 18th-century style rum punch." 

The man has an answer for everything.

section1List.hed: 8 Ways to Instantly Upgrade Your Summer Dips and Spreads
section1List.dek: Your chips won't know what hit them.
section1List.promoHed: Upgrade Your Summer Dips and Spreads
section1List.body:
Look, we've got nothing against plain hummus, pico de gallo, or freshly made guacamole. They're classic chip pairings for a reason. 

But we're obsessed with tinkering around with the dip blueprint in the Epicurious Test Kitchen, introducing all sorts of unexpected ingredients and flavors. We're looking to push the boundaries of what a dip or spread can be. Here are eight of the strategies we find ourselves going back to over and over again. 

A HANDFUL OF GREEN HERBS GOES A LONG WAY
--------------------------
This one's easy, but shouldn't be underestimated. Nearly any dipfrom tangy yogurt-based ones to creamy hummus-like numberscan be improved with a smattering of roughly chopped fresh herbs. Practically anything you've got on hand will dowe love basil, mint, dill, flat-leaf parsley, and sorrel (more info on that last one [here](http://www.epicurious.com/ingredients/what-is-sorrel-recipes-article)).

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4220e19925f464b378c97]||||||

GO CREAMY WITH TAHINI
---------------------
Sure you could make your dips creamy with, well, *cream*. But often times we turn to tahini for that. A thick paste made from ground sesame seeds, tahini adds a rich, roasted flavor without any of the usual sweetness one finds in seed and nut butters. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4221119925f464b378cbc]||||||

ROAST YOUR GARLIC
-----------------
Roasted garlic has a nuanced, subtle sweetness that you don't get with the raw stuff. Plus, it turns into a velvety paste that's easily incorporated into dips, virtually eliminating the possibly of biting into larger-than-you'd-like pieces of raw garlic. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a42f8b6529d92b2c0132cb]||||||

SWAP OUT YOGURT FOR LABNEH
--------------------------
Greek yogurt's a great base for dipsit adds fat, flavor, and body. Take things one step further by labneh, the Lebanese strained yogurt. It's even thicker and adds a punchy, sour note. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4221019925f464b378cb4]||||||

UPGRADE THOSE RED PEPPER FLAKES
------------------------------
Not familiar with [aleppo pepper](http://www.epicurious.com/ingredients/chile-flakes-aleppo-sichimi-togarashi-gochugaru-article)? It's got a slightly-hot, slightly-sweet profile that pairs well with rich, creamy dips and spreads. Use it like you would crushed red pepper flakesjust sprinkle a handful atop whatever you're serving. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a41f8919925f464b37769e]||||||

CHAR YOUR VEGETABLES 
-----------------------------------------
Tossing thinly-sliced onions, leeks, and scallions with a few glugs of good olive oil and some mayo and sour cream is great and all. But take things to the next level by charring the onions under your oven's broiler (or on the grillbecause summer) for 10-15 minutes. They'll take on an extra deep layer of flavor and hold up even better against their creamy surroundings. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a420dc19925f464b3780c2]||||||

ADD A SPICY BITE
----------------
If you're not looking for 5-alarm-level spiciness, consider employing fresh grated horseradish. It lends a sharp bite cuts through any fat or richness of anything you throw at it. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4562819925f464b391cd3]||||||

MAKE YOUR OWN SUPERCHARGED FLAVOR BOOSTERS
------------------------------------------
Garlic and onion powder are tried and true friends of the dipthey're a great way to instantly add an explosion of flavor to just about anything. Look to take your at-home dips to the next level by making your own powders. While it sounds fussy and complicated, [all you need to pull them off](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/secret-trick-best-french-onion-dip-article) is an oven with a pilot light and a bit of time. And it's so worth it. After all, they're [the secret to the best French Onion dip ever](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/secret-trick-best-french-onion-dip-article).

section1List.hed: The Secret to the Best Ever French Onion Dip
section1List.dek: Just like your mom used to makeexcept with hidden, DIY superflavor.
section1List.promoHed: The Secret to the Best Ever French Onion Dip
section1List.body:
The last thing I expected Cortney Burns to make was the best French Onion dip I've ever had. 

A bit of background: Burns is one half of the duo behind San Francisco's [Bar Tartine](http://www.bartartine.com/). Along with co-chef Nick Balla, the pair has garnered all sorts of critical acclaim for melding the food of Balla's Hungarian ancestry with ingredients and techniques from a mishmash of other cultures, from Asia to Scandinavia. She was in New York recently and stopped by the Epicurious Test Kitchen to do a little cooking from her and Balla's new book, [*Bar Tartine: Techniques & Recipes*](http://www.amazon.com/Bar-Tartine-Techniques-Cortney-Burns/dp/1452126461). 

"I don't know the last time I've made French Onion dip," says Burns. "But it's the first thing that popped into my head when we were talking." 

What we'd been talking about is the many flavored powders *Bar Tartine* delves intostuff like making powders out of yogurt, burnt bread, and rice. It's the kind of stuff a high-end restaurant like Bar Tartine is built upon, but not something home cooks get into very often. But when we were talking, Burns suggested garlic and onion powder. Which, truthfully, I avoid. While it *can* be a potent flavor bomb, the store-bought stuff is doctored up with preservatives, extra salt, and artificial additives. Burns assured me that trying homemade garlic and onion powders would convert me: "They're just so concentrated in flavor, a little bit sweet, and incredibly versatileyou can fold them into breads, use them in marinades, or just about anything else."

And, as it turns out, they make for one hell of a dip.

Luckily, making your own garlic and onion powders is a heck of a lot easier than it sounds. Sure, you could use a dehydrator to do it, but there's an easier wayone with zero special equipment necessary. All you need is a gas oven. Don't turn it on, don't even look at itthe warmth of your oven's pilot light is enough to do the trick. The key to killer at-home powders is doing absolutely nothing.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/552bd64a20ca5d650ed234c7]||||||

+++

Start by prepping the green onions and garlic. For the green onions, trim the roots and halve the onions lengthwise from the white bottom all the way to the green top. Cut crosswise into 1-inch pieces and cook in a cast iron skillet over high heat until charred and blackened, about 10 minutes. For the garlic, peel the cloves, remove the hard stem end, and cut into very thin slices. 

From there, the process is the same for either powder: Place the ingredients on a sheet tray lined with parchment paper and leave it in a gas oven overnight. After 12 hours, remove the tray from the oven and grind the large dried pieces in a food processor to coarse flakes. Move the flakes back to a parchment-lined sheet tray and place in the oven for 8 more hours, until all the moisture is dried out. Process the results in a spice grinder and pass the powder through a fine mesh sieve. 

That's it. Active time where you're actually *doing* something? Oh, maybe 15 minutes. 

Don't have a gas oven? No problem, you've still got options. Of course, there's always a [food dehydrator](http://www.bedbathandbeyond.com/store/product/excalibur-5-tray-stackable-dehydrator-and-jerky-machine/1043262427?mcid=PS_googlepla_nonbrand_kitchenelectrics_&adpos=1o5&creative=39230283949&device=c&matchtype=&network=g&gclid=Cj0KEQjwmLipBRC59O_EqJ_E0asBEiQATYdNh3UXSpDuMDTdaBWsBCDtnpWOndJt2kGTCwAcmSbkPlUaAghB8P8HAQ) (set it to 125F and follow the same time guidelines above). Following the same process with an electric oven set to its lowest setting (ideally below 170 F) and the door ajar works well too. 

With the super-concentrated flavor of garlic and charred green onions at your finger tips, assembling the best ever French onion dip is a breeze. Burns turns to rich, creamy ricotta cheese over the more conventional mayo for a dip that packs a lighter mouthfeel. Combine __1 1/2 cups high-quality ricotta cheese__ and __sour cream__ with __1/4 cup chopped fresh chives__, __1 cup caramelized onions__,  __2 tbsp charred green onion powder__, __2 tbsp garlic powder__, and __2 tbsp sweet paprika__. Fold with a rubber spatula until fully incorporated. 

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/552bd625b329bd276d93fe2f]||||||

+++

The resulting dip tastes nothing like the stuff you had growing up as a kid. It's rich, creamy, slightly sweet, a little bit salty, and full of multi-layered, big flavors. And it's all because we put a few ingredients in an oven. "It's one of those simple things that sounds complicated at first," explains Burns, "but then you do it and you realize, oh wait, this is the easiest thing ever." 

The hardest thing ever? Putting down the bowl.

section1List.dek: One ingredient is nothing. Two is too basic. But three ingredients? Now you're cooking.
section1List.body:
There's [a magic one-ingredient sauce](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-make-brown-butter-article), but there's no magic one-ingredient dish. Because a one-ingredient dish is just, um, one ingredient. On a dish.

Two-ingredient dishes? Yeah, there are a few of those. I can think of cheese and crackers...yogurt and honey...apples and peanut butter. Am I the only one having flashbacks to kindergarten?

It's when you get to three ingredients that things start to pop. Three ingredients can be a pasta dinner. It can be an ice cream sundae. It can certainly be breakfast.

But as the easy (and very, very fast) suggestions below demonstrate, three is really the magic number when it comes to appetizers.

####Button Mushrooms + Boursin Cheese + Bread Crumbs####
Stem the mushrooms. Stuff with cheese. Top with the bread crumbs. Bake at 400F until golden.

####Feta + Chili Oil + Mint####
Put feta in a baking dish. Drizzle with oil. Bake at 350F until golden. Strew with torn mint and attack with forks.

####Fresh Figs + Bacon + Honey####
Wrap figs in enough bacon to cover. Bake at 350F until the bacon is crispy. Drizzle with honey and debate whether this is an app or dessert.

####Cherry Tomatoes + Sour Cream + Herbs####
Core the tomatoes. Spoon in sour cream. Top with chopped herbs.

####Edamame + Chili Flakes + Lime####
Cook edamame in a hot pan with oil until blistered. Top with chili flakes and a squeeze of lime.


+++landscape

[#image: /photos/54dcdfb1e77a7de93305d239]||||||

+++

####Melon + Prosciutto + Mint####
Slide melon pieces, prosciutto, and basil leaves onto a skewer. Drop the mic.

####Goat Cheese + Apricots + Toasted Pistachios####
Chop apricots. Stir into goat cheese. Form cheese into cute, tiny balls. Roll in toasted, chopped pistachios.

####Chicken Wings + Melted Butter + Hot Sauce####
Season wings. Roast in a 400F oven, on a wire rack set over a rimmed baking sheet, until crispy-skinned and cooked through. Toss in a big bowl with the butter and hot sauce.

####Triscuits + [Sardines](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/canned-fish-sardines-tuna-anchovies-dinner-party-article) + Mustard####
Open box of Triscuits. Slather with mustard. Top with sardines.

####Campari + Vermouth + Club Soda####
What, you've never drunk your apps before?

section1List.hed: Why You Should Never Buy Hummus Again
section1List.dek: All it takes is 5 minutes for DIY hummus glory.
section1List.promoHed: Why You Should Never Buy Hummus Again
section1List.socialDescription: It only takes 5 minutes to make this dip at home.
section1List.body:
Hummus might be too easy. Easy to pick up and toss in the cart, easy to carry to a summer picnic, and easy to dip practically anything into. But why always resort to storebought hummus? Why not make it yourself?

Homemade hummus is super easy, cheaper than buying storebought, and endlessly customizable to your tastes. At its most basic, it's only five things: chickpeas, tahini, lemon juice, garlic, and olive oil. But once you start making it yourself, you'll see just how much possibility this dip actually holds.

So go buy some fresh tahini, pull out the food processor, and follow these steps to homemade hummus heaven.

####Blend to Taste####
We'll usually lean towards a grit-free hummus blend, but sometimes we want something that's chip-shatteringly thick and chunky. This is why you make it at home. For a hummus that wallops, go heavier on the chickpeas and garlic. If you want it creamier, add more tahini or peel your chickpeas (more on that next).

[#recipe: /recipes/54a42e5e6529d92b2c012309]||||||

####The Deal on the Peel####
Chickpeas have a small skin on the outside that can be pinched and peeled off, leaving the plump beans underneath. Removing the peel makes a more uniform blend. The end result is a lot richer and almost buttery smooth, and it'll only take 10 minutes to knock out a batch of chickpeas.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4214a6529d92b2c0087c2]||||||

####Roast Your Hummus####
Pureeing some [roasted garlic](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/roasted-garlic-102291) is a quick way to add deep, mellowed garlic flavor. If you're grilling something, throw a [squash directly onto the coals](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/ember-roasted-squash-hummus-51170410) or an eggplant onto the grill grate. When soft, peel, puree, and add the sweet-and-smoky base to your hummus for something that's unlike anything that comes in a plastic tub.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4200719925f464b377a44]||||||

####Spice is Nice####
Crazy about sriracha? Add a few drops to make it crow. Or stir in some [fresh paprika or ground cumin](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/hummus-358329). Try it with a few spoonfuls of [harissa paste](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/sweet-and-tangy-hummus-51239620), a Tunisian spice that brings a tanginess (careful, a little goes a long way). [A can of chipotles](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/smoky-chipotle-hummus-with-garlic-bagel-chips-105661) will add some smokey spice.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a421886529d92b2c008a67]||||||

####Give it a Rest####
Let a home-blended hummus rest for at least 15 minutes so the flavors can meld, but we won't tell anyone if you let a few stray carrots scrape the blender's side for "quality assurance."

[#recipe: /recipes/54a427256529d92b2c00c73d]||||||

####The Dressing on Top####
For both looks and extra richness, you'll want to drizzle oil across your final hummus. You can get creative by making your own [infused garlic oil](http://www.epicurious.com/ingredients/how-to-make-garlic-infused-olive-oil-article) or one that's got all of the savory [flavor punch of an everything bagel](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes-menus/irrestistable-everything-bagel-yogurt-lamb-chops-article).


[#recipe: /recipes/54a41fd519925f464b3778cb]||||||

section4List.hed: Turn Leftover Potato Salad Into Crispy Roasted Potatoes
section4List.dek: This may be the most effortless magic trickum, *recipe*of all time.
section4List.promoHed: These Crispy Roasted Potatoes Used to Be Potato Salad
section4List.body:
After a recent cookout, my boyfriend and I found ourselves staring down leftover potato salad. Mountains of it.

It took up nearly a full shelf in the refrigerator.  It was delicious, but, frankly, there is only so much potato salad two people can eat. So, beyond throwing it away or, I don't know, feeding some of it to the dog, what could we do?

Roast it.

[#article: /articles/55674b665fa91f011a455b3c]||||||

It was a pretty simple potato salad: large cubes of potatoes, skin on, tossed with mayonnaise, mustard, salt, pepper, red wine vinegar, and the last of the season's chopped ramps. Mayonnaise is mostly oil, and the rest of it amounts to seasoning, so we figured toss it in the oven and see what happens. 

And guess what? [It worked](https://instagram.com/p/3KoH4fBcKv/?taken-by=forbespa): after about half an hour in the oven, we had crispy, browned potato chunks you'd never guess were potato salad in a past life.

##How on Earth Does That Work?##

Turns out, [potato salad recipes](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/lemony-potato-salad-354231) and [roasted potato recipes](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/crispy-shaken-potatoes-with-rosemary-51244610) are not that different from each other. Stay with me: both call for potatoes to be cut into chunks, boiled, tossed with oil (or mayonnaise) and seasonings. Potato salad stops there, while crispy potatoes are chucked into a hot oven until their exteriors turn golden.

But don't take my word for it. I had the Epicurious Test Kitchen make up one of our [most popular potato salad recipes](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/lemony-potato-salad-354231) exactly as writtenno funny business here, promiseand try roasting it. It worked for them, too: both in the oven *and* in a cast iron skillet on the stove top.

##How to Do it at Home##

Take your favorite potato salad recipe. (We haven't tested it with every kind of potato salad, although the simpler the recipe, the better. Let us know how it works if you try it with [German-style potato salad](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/german-potato-salad-with-dill-51236500)!) Don't be afraid to use potato salads that have chunks of celery or herbs in them; it'll add to the end result.

Most potato salads can go straight into a cast iron pan. If your potato salad is really, really mayonnaise-y (ours was), toss it into a strainer and give it a quick rinse. Don't rinse off all the mayo, thoughyou want some fat on there so the potatoes crisp up.

Preheat the oven to 425. (Toaster ovens are your best friend if it's hot out.) Cook the potatoes for about half an hour, shaking them in the pan every ten minutes or so, until they're golden brown.

And that's it: a new life for old potato salad.

section4List.hed: Potato Salad Problems (And How to Fix Them)
section4List.dek: Troubleshooting all your potato salad hangups.
section4List.seoTitle: How to Fix Potato Salad Problems
section4List.seoDescription: Consider your potato salad problems solved.
section4List.socialTitle: Potato Salad Problems (And How to Fix Them)
section4List.socialDescription: Consider your potato salad problems solved.
section4List.body:
Of all of the foods [you should make yourself](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/foods-to-stop-buying-making-grocery-store-article), potato salad is screaming for some DIY magic. The stuff in the tub at the store is just scary, and the deli counter's potato salad sits soaked in so much mayo, you might think you're eating soup, not salad.

And it's summer, which is no time for soup.

But the path to good, homemade potato salad is not always an easy one. Overcooked potatoes might turn your salad into a mash, or a thick, uninteresting salad dressing may leave your salad bland. You may even encounter the dreaded undercooked tuber, ruining an otherwise perfectly good salad. Whatever your gripe, we've got a fix for it.

####Problem: Bland Potatoes####
__Solution: Season Your Water With Salt and Herbs__

Before bringing your potatoes to a boil, add salt and sprigs of parsley to the stockpot of cold water. This step brings so many extra opportunities for flavor infusion in the potatoesadd garlic if you like, or a tablespoon of vinegar to help the potatoes get even punchier.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4230719925f464b379402]||||||

####Problem: Dressing That Just Doesn't Work####
__Solution: Toss Your Taters While They're Hot__

When you toss warm potatoes in dressing, they'll absorb some of the dressing, producing a sort of magical cohesion and better flavor all around. For oil-based salads, toss the potatoes with dressing and vinaigrette when the potatoes are hot. If using a mayo-based dressing, stir in the potatoes when theyre warm, not hotyou don't want to break the mayo.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a426fe19925f464b37c133]||||||

####Problem: Soggy Potato Texture####
__Solution: Smart Shopping and a Steam__

So much of your final potato salad's texture is based on potato choice. A waxy potato has a great texture and keeps its shape when cooked. Use small baby red potatoes, fingerlings, or baby new potatoes. They won't break up too much while you're mixing, keeping most of your salad intact. Some of these have such soft skins, they dont even require peeling.

If your waxy potatoes are still soggy, try steaming them in a basket. You wont get the same kind of flavorful potato that a seasoned boiling creates, but youll be able to avoid overcooking easier.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a42e256529d92b2c011fff]||||||

####Problem: Overly Heavy Dressing####
__Solution: Brighten Up Your Seasonings__

Use [pickle juice](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/eggy-potato-salad-with-pickles-395434), [buttermilk](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/potato-salad-with-buttermilk-dressing-103774), and additional vinegar to freshen up a heavy dressing. A [squeeze of lemon never hurt](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/lemony-potato-salad-354231), either. If you have fresh herbs or scallion greens around, chop and toss them into the potato salad for some additional crunch and call it [a green goddess](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/green-goddess-potato-salad-238694) potato salad. 

And while we're on the topic of lighter dressings, let's just think outside of mayo altogether. German potato salads, tossed in a vinegar-laced dressing, are mouth-puckering, bacon-crusted, and way too underrated. Rhoda Boone, our Food Editor, loves a warm [bacon-mustard vinaigrette](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/mashed-root-vegetables-with-bacon-vinaigrette-51124250) on the potatoes. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a41ead19925f464b377067]||||||

####Problem: Deadly Mayonnaise####
__Solution: Put Your Salad on Ice__

And the biggest question: how long can a potato salad sit out before getting bad? Around four hours unrefrigerated (and out of the sun) is the max for mayo-based saladsat that point, it's been in the "danger zone" between 40F and 140F for too long. To keep potato salad safer longer, fill a larger bowl with ice for nesting the potato salad bowl, and always keep it out of direct light.

section4List.hed: 3 Ways to Make Salad a Summer Superstar
section4List.dek: How to take them beyond mere health food.
section4List.promoHed: 3 Ways to Supercharge Your Summer Salads
section4List.seoTitle: How to Upgrade Your Summer Salads
section4List.socialTitle: 3 Ways to Make Salad the Star of Summer
section4List.body:
When was the last time a salad stopped you in your tracks? One that you ate because you loved it, not because it was the healthy-thing-you-eat-alongside-something-less-healthy-to-feel-better-about-yourself option?

Sure, salad can be good. Of-the-moment produce, a killer dressing, and herbed croutons aren't ever bad by any measure. But what does it take for a pile of produce to go from merely good to unquestionably awesome? 

In a word, can salad ever be *great*?

That's the question associate food editor Anna Stockwell and I tackled recently within the walls of the Epicurious Test Kitchen. And the answer was simple. The best salads are the ones that combine the flavors, textures, and techniques that makes all food great: Fat, acid, spice, and crunch, with a combination of flavors: raw, pickled, creamy, nutty, etc. 

The three summer salads we came up with personify three of our favorite salad-making strategies. They're recipes you'll want to make over and over again, for sure (at least we hope so). But you can also think of them as ideas to riff off all summer long.

GO WITH THE GRILL (and the Grains)
--------------------------------
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/5570961a81ac1e5023671944]||||||

+++

We all know the charcoal grill is the centerpiece of summertime cooking. But you don't need to swear off your Weber just because you're having salad for dinner. Toss fennel, cherry tomatoes, scallions, and a slab of cumin-rubbed skirt steak on the grill so they all pick up that unmistakable charred, smoky flavor we crave as soon as the thermostat hits 75 degrees. 

Then, swap out romainesteak salad's usual partner in crimefor a mix of cooked quinoa and French lentils, which won't wilt under the warm, grilled ingredients toppings. 

For a dressing, head towards the Mediterranean by marrying thick, tangy Greek yogurt with tahini, the thick Middle Eastern sesame paste that tastes especially great with grains and legumes.

[#recipe: /recipes/5570a84881ac1e5023671d05]||||||

LIGHTEN UP A CLASSIC
----------------
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/5570960481ac1e5023671892]||||||

+++

Don't get us wrongwe're big fans of classic bean salad. It's the easiest, cheapest way to get protein in a salad on those nights when we either don't feel like eating meat or just don't have it around. But the mild flavors do seem to need a bit of a wake-up call. Don't worry, we fixed that problem.

Our upgraded take on the classic pairs kidney, pinto, white, green, and yellow wax beans with a rich, Spanish-influenced olive oil spiked with smoked paprika and cayenne pepper. And, because it's summer, the whole thing gets lightened up with fresh parsley and ribbons of celery. 

[#recipe: /recipes/5570a7ba81ac1e5023671d03]||||||

SPICE UP A CREAMY DRESSING
-----------------------------------------
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/5570960474cbe9ed7c207af0]||||||

+++

This last one's downright addictive. Take a creamy, mayo-based dressing and fortify it with fresh lime juice and horseradish, which adds a spicy bite to anything it comes across. (If you can find it fresh, grate up a bit less than a half the amount of the bottled stuff in the recipe.) The zesty bite of this dressing is as refreshing on a hot day as an ice-cold beer.

The vehicle for the creamy-spicy dressing of our dreams? A mess of crisp Bibb lettuce, shredded rotisserie chicken, tart cherries, and breadcrumbsbecause everything's better when it's [crunchy](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-make-anything-crunchy-article). 

[#recipe: /recipes/5570a74974cbe9ed7c207f42]||||||

section4List.hed: The Italian Secret to Great Pasta Salad
section4List.dek: How one tip from a Tuscan farm cook changed our pasta game forever.
section4List.promoHed: The Italian Secret to Great Pasta Salad
section4List.body:
The summer after I graduated college I put off being a real person and ran off to Tuscany to intern on an organic farm. It was a perfect four months: I planted. I harvested. I ate double my weight in the best Italian food I've ever tasted.

That food was prepared by the farm's cook, a woman named Graziella. As is the Italian way, pasta was often at the center of the table. But on those hot, Tuscan afternoons in late July, when the temperature inched up to 100 F, not even the Italians wanted hot bowls of pasta. So Graziella made pasta salad instead. 

But Graziella's pasta salad didn't taste like the many I'd eaten at backyard barbecues here in the States. There was an undertone to them, a background flavor that was in every bite, but was hard to identify.

When I finally cobbled together enough Italian to ask Graziella how she made her pasta, I realized what I was tasting: garlic. But not minced or crushed or sliced garlic. No, Graziella used the *essence* of garlic. And she found that essence in just one clove, which she rubbed on the inside of the bowl that she'd eventually be tossing the pasta in.

Now I use garlic *essence* too. This is how it's done: Grab a bowl (it doesn't matter whether it's wood, glass, or even plastic), peel a garlic clove, halve it, and rub the cut side of each half all over the inside surface of the bowl. Throw in vegetables like chopped tomatoes or summer squash, and add a handful of fresh herbs, some salt, and some pepper. Add some just-cooked, still-warm pasta to the bowl and toss with the vegetables and herbs, drizzling with olive oil as you go. The olive oil-dressed pasta will pick up the garlic juices in the bowl, coating every strand in a gentle dose of sweet, garlicky flavor. Eat the pasta while it's still warm or wait until it's a more cookout-friendly room temperatureeither way, Graziella would approve.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4204419925f464b377c20]|||
Pasta with Tomatoes and Mozzarella
|||

items.caption: With dill, a little goes a long way. But for a big potato salad like this, a little just isn't enough.
Bacon and eggs: once relegated to the breakfast table, now a stroke of genius side for a summer potluck.
This simple summertime noodle dinner can easily be adapted for a crowd. These delicious and light Mediterranean flavors were meant to be shared.
If you're headed somewhere fancy, pack this toasted buckwheat and cold squash salad along. It's best with plenty of scallions and marjoram for freshness and feta for creamy richness.
Chop broccoli and napa cabbage together and what do you have? The crunchiest, greenest summer slaw we could think of. Add chives and snap peas for some liveliness.
Potato and egg salad: It's a collision, but it's not a train wreck. Bonus: the eggs only take seven minutes.
This incredible red cabbage and green snap pea chopped salad is nothing short of crunchy. Toss them with a honey-mint dressing for a cooling and sweet accent.
We're about as over penne pasta salads as the next person, but this salad with whimsically shaped gemelli, fresh mozzarella, and a scratch-made olive condiment is fresh and tasty.
Kick the can and go fresh with this smoky and tangy bean salad. Using bright celery and parsley livens up this salad for the potluck table.
Orzo, the Italian word for barley, is a slender grain that gives extra bite to this salad of arugula, radicchio, and mozzarella.

Here's a pasta salad for the overachievers out there. Julienne your vegetables fine over brown rice spaghetti and toss in some cooked shrimp for a sweet seafood flavor. Get ready to steal the show with this one.
The taste of Buffalo wings without the mess. Crumble up blue cheese on top and don't be afraid to have one more.
items.credit: Photo by Kathy Casey Food Studios

items.caption: Can't score fava beans? Sub in lima beans or butter beans. This wild rice and pistachio salad hits all of the right notes.
Get grain power on your side salad. This barley and chickpea salad has a lot of nutty flavor.
The crisp-tender texture and robust flavor of thinly sliced Tuscan kale stands up to the tart, Caesar-like dressing of this hearty slaw.

Make a quick swing by the produce aisle, and with little preparation, this black rice salad is ready for your next summer get-together. Don't forget the toasted walnutsthey're the real deal-sealer here.

section4List.hed: How to Turn Vegetables Into Chips
section4List.body:
Yes, you can make homemade [potato chips](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/crispiest-potato-chips-51252630) and they'll be amazing, but why not think beyond the potato? The most surprising and exciting kinds of chips you can make though aren't made of potatoes at all: they're made from vegetables. 

[#article: /articles/5580866781ac1e502367706a]||||||

There's a whole array of vegetables waiting to be turned into addictive salty crunchy snacks, and you don't necessarily need to deep frying them to do so. Many root vegetables and hearty leafy greens can get chipified right in your oven.

Just slice them as thin as you can (a mandoline is your best friend here) or tear them into chip-sized, individual leaves, then make sure they're as dry as dry can be. Pat them with towels, leave them out to air-dry, do whatever you need to do to make sure there's as little moisture on them as possible. 

Brush or toss them with some oil, season to taste, line them up on a baking sheet, and roast in a hot oven until nice and crispy. The best temperature and time depends on the ingredient you're using. And of course, some ingredients will get crispier when fried in oil instead. 

Here's how to turn all sorts of vegetables into chips:

####Kale####
At this point, you've probably had kale chips before. But have you made them? It's easier than you think. Try [tossing them in some Parm](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/parmesan-pepper-curly-kale-chips-51142280) before roasting them in the oven, or stick with just olive oil. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a42c2b19925f464b3800ba]||||||

####Beets####
Even the beet-averse will love these slightly sweet oven-baked chips. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a420f719925f464b37818e]||||||

####Parsnips and Carrots####
Frying thin ribbons of carrots and parsnips in two inches of oil turns them into wavy twists of addictive sweet crunch. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a41ea419925f464b37701e]||||||

####JERUSALEM ARTICHOKE ####
The potato-like texture of jerusalem artichokes means they work particularly well as deep-fried chips. A lemony thyme dip turns them into a crowd-pleasing snack. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a45fd119925f464b394b3f]||||||

####Cabbage####
For the higher moisture content of cabbage leaves, you need a slow and low roast in the oven (or dehydrator, if you're into that) to get them crispy. You can use any kind of cabbage you like and keep it simple with [just the leaves and some salt](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/savoy-cabbage-chips-51143900) or you can brush with olive oil and spices for a bit more flavor and texture.  

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4220c6529d92b2c008fad]||||||
